discription: A long time ago, there lived a beautiful woman called Vidyullatha in Vijayanagar.

character: learned lady accomplished all genres fine arts: FEMALE
discription: She was a learned lady who was accomplished in all genres of fine arts.

character: learned lady accomplished all genres fine arts: FEMALE
dialogue: 1: “A reward of one thousand gold coins would be presented to those who would be able to defeat me in humour, wit and knowledge of ancient texts.”

discription: This became an issue of prestige for all the scholars in the region.
Many of them took up the challenge and tried to defeat Vidyullatha in the war of words, but none succeeded.
One morning, a vendor happened to pass by her house selling firewood.

dialogue: 1: “Firewood ..strong firewood….Who wants my strong and long lasting firewood?”

discription: The vendor had a shrill voice and was shouting continuously which irritated Vidyullatha.
Just tell me how much do you want for it, but please stop shouting.”

dialogue: 1: “Madam, I will not sell this for money. If you can give me a handful grain I will readily give you all the firewood that I have.”

discription: Vidyullatha promised him to give what he wanted and ordered him to dump the load in the backyard.

dialogue: 1: “I need a handful of grain, Madam. Have you understood me clearly?”

1: “You are asking me whether or not I have understood what a handful of grains mean? I am the most learned lady in the entire district! I know what you want. Now stop arguing and put this firewood in the backyard.”
1: “Madam, I pity you! You really do not know what I want. If you cannot pay the price, you should pay me one thousand gold coins and wipe the invitation hoarding on the compound wall.”

1: “This is no nonsense.I told you the price and you agreed for it.Now if you cannot pay the price, you must give me one thousand gold coins for you have clearly failed to understand what I meant.And considering that, I have defeated you in the war of words.”

discription: A heated argument ensued between the two and then Vidyullatha decided to approach the provincial Court of Law for justice.

dialogue: 1: “My Lord! This firewood vendor is crazy.He asked for a handful of grains in lieu of his load of firewood.I agreed to give him that but he keeps saying that I do not know what it means and wants me to wipe off the board in front of the house.I plead for justice!”

discription: The judge looked at the vendor and asked him what the matter was.

dialogue: 1: “Sir, I informed her beforehand that the load of firewood would cost her a handful grain.I actually wanted one grain that could fill the hand.If she cannot understand this much, she has no right to put up that hoarding in front of her house.”

discription: Vidyullatha was outwitted by the firewood vendor and the verdict was given in favour of the vendor.
Vidyullatha was ordered to pay him one thousand gold coins and ordered to take down the hoarding from her wall.
That witty vendor was none other than Tenaliram.
He had also heard about Vidyulalltha’s arrogance and haughtiness, and had thus taken the guise of a firewood vendor to teach her a lesson.
